member.summary: Actions represent high-level abstract operations such as movements, rotations, transformations or joint manipulations, both in absolute and relative terms. They are independent from the device's properties, and their translation into actual robotic instructions depends on the robot's properties and state.

member.summary: Returns the length of the rotation axis.

member.name: M:Machina.AxisAngle.Modulate
member.summary: Transforms this AxisAngle into a rotation around the same axis, but with an equivalent rotation angle in the [0, 360]. Note the axis vector will be flipped if the original angle was negative.

member.name: M:Machina.AxisAngle.Flip
member.summary: Flip this AxisAngle to represent the same rotation with inverted vector and opposite angle.

member.name: M:Machina.AxisAngle.IsEquivalent(Machina.AxisAngle)
member.summary:
Is this rotation equivalent to a given one? Equivalence is defined as rotations around vectors sharing the same axis (including opposite directions) and an angle with the same modulated equivalence. This in turn means the same spatial orientation after transformation. For example, the following rotations are equivalent: [0, 0, 1, 315] [0, 0, 1, 675] (one additional turn, same angle) [0, 0, 1, -45] (negative rotation, same angle) [0, 0, -1, 45] (flipped axis, same angle) [0, 0, 10, 315] (same axis and angle, longer vector. note non-unit vectors are not allowed in this AA representation)
Also, these are equivalent: [0, 0, 0, 0] [0, 0, 1, 720]

member.name: M:Machina.AxisAngle.ToQuaternion
member.summary: Returns a unit Quaternion representing this AxisAngle rotation.

member.name: M:Machina.AxisAngle.ToRotationVector
member.summary: Returns a RotationVector representing this AxisAngle rotation.

member.name: M:Machina.AxisAngle.ToRotationMatrix
member.summary: Returns a Rotation Matrix representation of this Axis Angle. Please note that rotation matrices represent rotations in orthonormalized coordinates, so that additional Axis Angle information such as overturns (angles outside [0, 180]) will get lost, and rotation axis might be flipped. If this Axis Angle represents no effective rotation, the identity matrix will be returned.

member.name: M:Machina.AxisAngle.ToYawPitchRoll
member.summary: Returns a YawPitchRoll representation of this rotation.

member.name: T:Machina.Orientation
member.summary: Defines an Orientation in three-dimensional space represented by a triplet of orthogonal XYZ unit vectors following right-hand rule orientations. Useful for spatial and rotational orientation operations.

members.member: NOTE: just as rotation, this class is just a wrapper around the underlying rotational elements that represent Orientation in space. The main purpose of this class it to be an intuitive way of representing Orientation in three-dimensional space. AxisAngle is therefore not used here, since conceptually there is no need to represent rotations or store overturns in an object that represents pure orientation. Typical inputs will be vectors in space or conversions from other rotation representations, and typical visual outputs will be main Vectors, Rotation Matrices or Euler Angles (even though all internal computation is based on Quaternion algebra).

member.name: P:Machina.Orientation.XAxis
member.summary: The main X direction of this Orientation.

member.summary: The main Y direction of this Orientation.

member.summary: The main Z direction of this Orientation.

member.summary: Implicit conversion from Rotation to Orientation via its Quaternion.

member.summary: Create a Rotation object representing no rotation.

member.name: M:Machina.Orientation.#ctor(Machina.Vector,Machina.Vector)
member.summary: Create a new Orientation object from the main X and Y axes. This constructor will create the best-fit orthogonal coordinate system respecting the direction of the X vector and the plane formed with the Y vector. The Z vector will be normal to this planes, and all vectors will be unitized.

member.name: M:Machina.Orientation.#ctor(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Create a new Orientation object from the main X and Y axes. This constructor will create the best-fit orthogonal coordinate system respecting the direction of the X vector and the plane formed with the Y vector. The Z vector will be normal to this planes, and all vectors will be unitized.

member.name: M:Machina.Rotation.Combine(Machina.Rotation,Machina.Rotation)
member.summary: Combine the effect of two Rotations. Please note that rotations will be applied in the order specified by the arguments in intrinsic coordinates, i.e. r1, then r2 over the new LOCAL transformed coordinate system. This means that, if you want to rotate a Rotation A with another Rotation B in GLOBAL coordinates, you will need to pre-multiply the rotations as in: Combine(B, A).

member.name: M:Machina.Quaternion.#ctor(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Create a Quaternion from its components: w + x * i + y * j + z * k For quaternions to be used as valid representations of spatial rotations, they need to be versors (unit quaternions). This constructor will automatically Vector-Normalize the resulting Quaternion. While this may restrict more general complex algebra, it will be useful in the context of robotics to keep quaternions tight this way ;)

member.summary: Turns this Quaternion into a Versor (unit length quaternion). If quaternion couldn't be normalized (zero-length), turns it into identity and return false.

member.name: M:Machina.Quaternion.NormalizeVector
member.summary: Normalizes the complex portion of this Quaternion (the rotation vector) maintaining the scalar portion (the rotation angle) the same. This is useful when coming from a rotation specified by non-unit vectors, to maintain angular spin. If the scalar is outside the [-1, 1] range, the entire quaternion will be normalized instead.

member.summary: Returns the subtraction of two quaternions.

member.name: M:Machina.Quaternion.Multiply(Machina.Quaternion)
member.summary: Post-Multiply this Quaternion by the specified one, a.k.a. this = this * q. Conceptually, this means that a Rotation 'q' in Local (intrinsic) coordinates is applied to this Rotation. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quaternion#Hamilton_product

member.name: M:Machina.Quaternion.PreMultiply(Machina.Quaternion)
member.summary: Premultiplies this Quaternion by the specified one, a.k.a. this = q * this. Conceptually, this means that a Rotation 'q' in Global (extrinsic) coordinates is applied to this Rotation. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quaternion#Hamilton_product

member.name: M:Machina.Quaternion.Multiplication(Machina.Quaternion,Machina.Quaternion)
member.summary: Returns the Hamilton product of the first quaternion by the second. Remember quaternion multiplication is non-commutative.

member.summary: Multiply this Quaternion by a scalar.

member.name: M:Machina.Quaternion.Scale(Machina.Quaternion,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns a new Quaternion equal to the original multiplied by a factor.

member.name: M:Machina.Quaternion.Divide(Machina.Quaternion)
member.summary: Divide this Quaternion by another one. In reality, this quaternion is post-multiplied by the inverse of the provided one.

member.name: M:Machina.Quaternion.Division(Machina.Quaternion,Machina.Quaternion)
member.summary: Returns the division of q1 by q2. Under the hood, q1 is post-multiplied by the inverse of q2.

member.name: T:Machina.ControlMode
member.summary: Represents the type of control that will be performed over the real/virtual robot.

member.name: F:Machina.ControlMode.Offline
member.summary: Not connected to any controller. Useful for robot code generation and export.

member.name: F:Machina.ControlMode.Execute
member.summary: Online connection to a controller, the library will upload complete programs and run them. Provides robust and fluid movement, useful on real-time interactivity where response time is not a priority.

member.name: F:Machina.ControlMode.Stream
member.summary: Online connection to a controller, the library will stream individual targets at run time as they get priority. Provides the closest approximation to real-time interaction, useful on situations where low latency is required.

member.summary: Defines the different modes a program can be ran.

member.summary: Defines which reference coordinate system to use for transform actions.

member.summary: Defines which type of motion to use for translation actions.;
